ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to speak Swahili.
A continuation of Kiswahili grammar concepts
I learned mainly the noun classes of Kiswahili, but these spread to a lot of different aspects of Kiswahili, from demonstratives to adjectives etc. etc, so this was very important to learn.
Continued/deeper development of Kiswahili grammar and structure.
I continue to grow in my understanding of the Swahili Language and the culture of East Africa

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: High engagement, reasonable workload
Weaknesses: N/A
Enriching class that fostered a great learning environment. No weaknesses!

The strengths are that you definitely learn more swahili. The weakness, which may have been cause it was online, is that each class is pretty similar and there is not much differentiation between them so it can sometimes be boring.
The class provided a lot of opportunities for developing speaking skills and confidence. I felt the pacing of the class was just right as well and that I had enough time to build up my vocabulary.

Strengths - Mwalimu is great and there is tons of support from both the other students and the other prof.
Weakness - sometimes the expectations were confusing on assignments and there was no organization or use of canvas so you never really know how you are doing in the class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: good is that mwalimu brought good energy to class. bad is that each class wasn't that different from eachother and could be boring-ish.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the personal connection between students and the professor facilitates the best possible learning. Everyone is very bought-in, and in turn, the class runs very smoothly.
yes if you want to learn swahili! it's a cool, beautiful language and not a hard class.
Yes, I thought this course was a great foundational language course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: we basically just met as a class every morning and learned and chatted in kiswahili!
It was mainly a recorded lecture, but the professor would record if a student was absent
